title: Question 26

children: A 68-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-week history of fever and malaise. Medical history is significant for kidney transplantation 9 months ago. Donor serology was positive for cytomegalovirus, and the patient was seronegative; he received valganciclovir prophylaxis for 6 months after transplantation. Medications are tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, prednisone, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
On physical examination, temperature is 38.1 °C (100.6 °F); other vital signs are normal. The physical examination is normal.
Which of the following infections is most likely present in this patient?

Cytomegalovirus infection remains a risk in solid organ transplant recipients after prophylaxis discontinuation if they were seronegative for the virus and received an organ from a seropositive donor.
Cytomegalovirus infection can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, hepatitis, bone marrow suppression, colitis, esophagitis, and adrenalitis in immunocompromised persons.
Cytomegalovirus is the most likely infection present in this patient (

). Several factors influence determining a causative pathogen in an organ transplant recipient. Knowing the timeline of common posttransplant infections is helpful, as is donor and recipient serostatus for infections like cytomegalovirus. The degree of risk and probability of an infection can also be determined by the patient's current prophylaxis. Because this patient was cytomegalovirus negative and the donor was seropositive, the patient was at very high risk for cytomegalovirus infection and its end-organ complications. He received 6 months of prophylaxis, which helped prevent early-onset cytomegalovirus infection and disease from the donor organ. However, when prophylaxis is stopped and immunosuppression is ongoing, late-onset cytomegalovirus infection and disease is a risk. Cytomegalovirus infection can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, hepatitis, bone marrow suppression, colitis, esophagitis, and adrenalitis in immunocompromised persons. Therefore, new-onset fever and malaise with laboratory evidence of cytopenia and liver enzyme elevation should prompt consideration for primary cytomegalovirus infection.

Polyomaviruses (BK and JC) contribute to morbidity in immunosuppressed patients, including organ transplant recipients (

). However, these infections tend to present 12 months or more after transplantation. BK virus typically causes more localized complications in kidney transplant recipients, especially tubulointerstitial nephritis and nephropathy. Similarly, syndromes caused by JC virus tend to be localized to the central nervous system. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is the most common presentation of JC virus infection; however, these infections are rare and are only seen in patients who have had more intense immunosuppression related to advancing age, other comorbidities, and frequent episodes of rejection. Patients present with focal neurologic deficits or seizures and have characteristic white matter changes on brain MRI. Polyomaviruses are unlikely to cause a syndrome like cytomegalovirus infection, including cytopenia and liver enzyme elevation.

objective.__html: Diagnose cytomegalovirus infection in a patient who has undergone solid organ transplantation.

references: Fishman JA. Infection in organ transplantation. Am J Transplant. 2017;17:856-879.
